title: Led by California, States Sue DOT Over Tailpipe-Emissions Dispute
text:
Traffic moves along U.S. 101 in Corte Madera, Calif., this week.

WASHINGTON—California, joined by 22 other states and the District of Columbia, sued the Trump administration Friday in a bid to preserve the state’s power to set tougher vehicle-emissions standards for the country’s auto industry.

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra filed the lawsuit in a Washington, D.C., federal court the day after officials from the Transportation Department and the Environmental Protection Agency announced new regulations to strip away California’s authority.

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, right, joined by Gov. Gavin Newsom this week, discussed the Trump administration's efforts to revoke California's authority on vehicle-emissions standards. Photo: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press

“California has been regulating vehicle emissions since 1959. Its authority to do so has been repeatedly recognized, reaffirmed, and even expanded by Congress,” the states said in the lawsuit. The new Trump administration effort “flies in the face of this history,” the states said.
